http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.02211v1.title: RR Lyrae Visual to Infrared Absolute Magnitude Calibrations. In the light of Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.02211v1.summary: A probabilistic approach has been used in combination with the parallax datafrom Gaia (e)DR3 to calibrate Period-Luminosity-(Abundance) (PLZ) Relations. The relation between $M_V$ and [Fe/H] is redetermined and as an illustration distances are given to a few selected objects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.02467v2.title: Efficient long-range AGN feedback affects the low redshift Lyman-$α$ forest
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.02467v2.summary: Active galactic nuclei (AGN) feedback models are generally calibrated to produce galaxy observables. We show that the low redshift Lyman-$\alpha$ forest can provide plausible evidence for long-range AGN jet feedback. We also show that TNG over-predicts the number density of absorbers at column densities $N_{\rm HI} < 1014}$

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04110v1.title: A nearly constant CN/HCN line ratio in nearby galaxies: CN as a new tracer of dense gas
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04110v1.summary: We measure a remarkably constant CN/HCN line intensity ratio of 0.86$$\pm$ 0.07 (standard deviation of0.20) We find that the CN/ HCN line ratio shows no significant correlation with molecular gas surface density, but shows a mild trend (increase of ~ 1.3 perex) with star formation rate surface density. The nearly constant ratio implies that CN can be used as atracer of dense gas mass and dense gas fraction in nearby galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04098v1.title: Validating Stellar Abundance Measurements from Multi-Resolution Spectroscopy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04098v1.summary: Large-scale surveys will provide spectroscopy for $\sim$50 million resolved stars in the Milky Way and Local Group. However, these data will have a highdegree of heterogeneity and most will be low-resolution ($R<10000$), posing challenges to measuring consistent and reliable stellar labels. By simultaneously fitting the full spectrum and Gaia photometry with the Payne, we can measure $40 abundances for 8 red giants in M15.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03932v3.title: Discovery of dusty sub-solar mass young stellar objects in NGC 346 with JWST/NIRCam
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.03932v3.summary: JWST observations of NGC 346 reveal a substantial population of sub-solar mass youngstellar objects (YSOs) with IR excess. For the first time in an extragalactic environment, we detect embedded low-mass star-formation. Evidence of IR excess and accretion suggests that dust required for rocky planet formation is present.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04067v1.title: Where intermediate-mass black holes could hide in the Galactic Centre: A full parameter study with the S2 orbit
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04067v1.summary: In the Milky Way the central massive black hole, SgrA*, coexists with a compact nuclear star cluster that contains a sub-parsec concentration of young stars. In several scenarios the presence of an intermediate-mass black hole (IMBH) has been invoked. We use spectroscopic data of S2 to investigate whether a second massive object could be present deep in the Galactic Centre.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.09925v2.title: Figuring Out Gas & Galaxies In Enzo (FOGGIE) VI: The Circumgalactic Medium of $L^*$ Galaxies is Supported in an Emergent, Non-Hydrostatic Equilibrium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.09925v2.summary: The circumgalactic medium (CGM) is often assumed to exist in or near Hydrostatic equilibrium. We investigate global hydrostatic equilibrium in the CGM using four highly-resolved $L^*$ galaxies from the Figuring Out Gas & Galaxies (FOGGIE) project. We find that global equilibrium models are neither appropriate nor predictive for the small scales probed by the FOGGIE.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04017v1.title: Understanding the progenitor formation galaxies of merging binary black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04017v1.summary: With nearly a hundred gravitational wave detections, the origin of black hole mergers has become a key question. Here, we focus on understanding the typicalgalactic environment in which binary black Hole mergers arise. We find that over 50% of BBH mergers have a progenitor metallicity of a few tenths of Solar metalicity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03989v1.title: Spectroscopic and evolutionary analyses of the binary system AzV 14 outline paths toward the WR stage at low metallicity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03989v1.summary: The origin of Wolf-Rayet (WR) stars in low-metallicity (low-Z) galaxies is not yet understood. Single-star evolutionary models predict that WRstars stem from very massive O-type star progenitors. On the other hand, binary evolutionary models say WR stars couldoriginate from primary stars in close binaries. Hotter WR stars might originate from primary worrisomestars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.17238v2.title: Gaia Data Release 3: All-sky classification of 12.4 million variable sources into 25 classes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.17238v2.summary: Gaia DR3 contains 1.8 billion sources with G-band photometry, 1.5 billion of which with BP and RP photometry. Supervised machine learning (eXtreme Gradient Boosting and Random Forest) was employed to generate multi-class, binary, and meta-classifiers. Classification results comprise 12.4 million sources and include about 9 million Variable stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03968v1.title: Assessing indirect methods to determine black hole masses using NGC 4151
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03968v1.summary: Accurately determining the black hole mass ($M_\mathrm{BH}$) in active galaxies is crucial to constraining their properties and to studying their evolution. Only indirect methods can be applied to heavily absorbed type 2 AGN, which represent most of the world's population.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03963v1.title: Could Nucleobases form in the ISM? A Theoretical Study in the Hoursehead nebula
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03963v1.summary: The Horseheadnebula is a region considered an archetype of molecular cloud. The model showed that at leastcytosine and uracil presented significant abundances. No insurmountable energybarrier which would prevent the reactions was found. The results of the study were published in the journal of theoretical physics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.11022v2.title: Dusty plasma in active galactic nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.11022v2.summary: Dust in the form of the dusty-molecular torus is responsible for the obscuration in active galactic nuclei (AGN) at large viewing angles. Recently, we gained some insights into geometry of the region and the role of the dust in the dynamics of the outflow and failed winds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2103.15153v3.title: A new catalogue of head-tail radio galaxies from LoTSS DR1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2103.15153v3.summary: The unique morphology of head-tail (HT) radio galaxies suggests that radio                jets and their intra-cluster medium interact strongly. We conducted a systematically search for HT radio galaxies using the LOFAR Two-metre Sky Survey. The opening angle between jets in WATradio galaxies is greater than ninety degrees, exhibiting wide `C'-likemorphologies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12838v2.title: First estimate of the local value of the baryonic streaming velocity
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12838v2.summary: For the first time, we constrain the local value of the SV in which the Milky Way was formed. We use the semi-analytical model A-SLOTH to simulate the formation of galaxies. The SV delays star formation at high redshift. At redshift z=0, the SV has no effect on the total stellar mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03834v1.title: Active galactic nuclei feedback in an elliptical galaxy (III): the impacts and fate of cosmological inflow
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03834v1.summary: The inflow of gas into a galaxy is speculated to be able to enhance the star formation rate (SFR) and black hole accretion rate (BHAR) In this paper, we investigate the fate of the inflow and its impacts on the evolution of a massive elliptical galaxy. We find that, the gas hardly enters but is blocked beyond the central galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03791v1.title: The mass-loss rates of star clusters with stellar-mass black holes: implications for the globular cluster mass function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03791v1.summary: Stellar-mass black holes (BHs) can be retained in globular clusters (GCs) until the present. Simulations of GC evolution find that the relaxation drivenmass-loss rate is elevated if BHs are present, especially near dissolution. Low-metallicity GCs have the highest mass-loss rates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03718v1.title: New dwarf galaxy candidates in the sphere of influence of the Local Volume spiral galaxy NGC2683
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03718v1.summary: The paper presents initial results of a survey of host galaxies environments in the Local Volume ($D<10\,$Mpc) Using the wide-field Hyper Suprime-Cam imager on the 8m SubaruTelescope. Direct inspection of the images has revealed 4 new satellite galaxy candidates, 2 of which have been independently discovered.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03564v1.title: FAUST VII. Detection of A Hot Corino in the Prototypical Warm Carbon-Chain Chemistry Source IRAS 15398-3359
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03564v1.summary: We have observed the low-mass protostellar source, IRAS 15398$-$3359, as part of the Atacama LargeMillimeter/Submillimeter Array Large Program FAUST. We detect nine CH$_3$OH lines, including the high excitation lines with upper state energies up to 500 K. These results, in combination with previous reports, indicate that IRAS is a source with hybrid properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03556v1.title: Paper 1: The JWST PEARLS View of the El Gordo Galaxy Cluster and of the Structure It Magnifies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03556v1.summary: The massive galaxy cluster El Gordo ($z=0.87$) imprints multitudes of digitally lensed arcs onto James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) images. Eight bands of NIRCam imaging were obtained in the Prime Extragalactic Areas for Reionization and Lensing Science program (GTO #1176)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.12804v2.title: Can Cosmological Simulations Reproduce the Spectroscopically Confirmed Galaxies Seen at $z\geq 10$?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.12804v2.summary: The JADES survey has detected the most distantgalaxies with spectroscopically confirmed redshifts. We find that existing models for cosmological galaxy formation can generally reproduce the observations. The results all rest on the confirmation of these distances by spectroscopy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09130v2.title: New Generation Stellar Spectral Libraries in the Optical and Near-Infrared I: The Recalibrated UVES-POP Library for Stellar Population Synthesis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.09130v2.summary: We present re-processed flux calibrated spectra of 406 stars from the                UVES-POP stellar library in the wavelength range 320-1025 nm. The spectra are provided in the two versions having spectral resolving power R=20,000 and R=80,000. For 364 stars from our sample, we provide projected projected rotational velocity and radial velocity estimates. The absolute flux uncertainty is better than 2% for about half of the stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.01369v2.title: How the super-Eddington regime affects black hole spin evolution in high-redshift galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.01369v2.summary: Three-dimensional hydrodynamical simulations of a galaxy in anisolated dark matter halo. We follow the evolution of the spin parameter $a$ of a black hole (BH) undergoing super-Eddington phases. This is suspected to be accompanied by powerful jet outflows, which are expected to increase the BH spin.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.08766v2.title: How the super-Eddington regime regulates black hole growth in high-redshift galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2201.08766v2.summary: Super-Eddington accretion is one scenario that may explain the rapid assembly of supermassive black holes (BHs) within the first billion years of the Universe. By means of hydrodynamical simulations of BH evolution in an isolated galaxy and its host halo with 12 pc resolution, we investigate how super-EDDington feedback affects the mass growth of the BH. We find that simulations with weak jet feedback efficienciesprovide a slightly larger BH mass evolution over long periods of time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03392v1.title: A Multiwavelength Classification and Study of Red Supergiant Candidates in NGC 6946
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03392v1.summary: We have combined resolved stellar photometry from Hubble Space Telescope, Spitzer, and Gaia to identify red supergiant (RSG) candidates in NGC~6946. We classify 95 potential RSGs, with 40 of these being in our highest-quality sample. Three of our candidates appear significantly more consistent with binary models than single-star evolution models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03438v1.title: X-ray Unveiling Events in a z~1.6 Active Galactic Nucleus in the 7 Ms Chandra Deep Field-South
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03438v1.summary: We investigate the extreme X-ray variability of a z = 1.608 active galacticucleus in the 7 Ms Chandra Deep Field-South (XID 403) XID 403 showed two significant X-rays brightening events. The extreme variability is likely due to two X-Ray unveilingevents, where the line of sight to the corona is no longer shielded by dust.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03420v1.title: Parameters of 220 million stars from Gaia BP/RP spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03420v1.summary: We train our model on stellar atmospheric parameters from the LAMOST survey. We model the XP spectra with all of their covariances, augmented by 2MASS and WISE photometry. The modeling procedure alsoproduces an estimate of the optical extinction curve.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03419v1.title: The Universe is at Most 88% Neutral at z=10.6
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03419v1.summary: Recent observations of GN-z11 with JWST have revealed a Ly$\alpha$ emission line with an equivalent width of 18$\pm 2$ angstroms. At z=10.6, this galaxy isexpected to lie in the heart of reionization. We use a series of inhomogeneousreionization simulations to derive the distribution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03417v1.title: Spectrally resolved cosmic rays -- III. Dynamical impact and properties of the circumgalactic medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03417v1.summary: Cosmic rays (CRs) are dynamically important for the formation and evolution of galaxies by regulating star formation and by powering galactic outflows. To what extent CRs regulate galaxy formation depends on the couplingstrength of CRs with the ambient plasma and the effective CR transport speed along the magnetic field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03412v1.title: From Carbon to Cobalt: Chemical compositions and ages of $z\sim0.7$ quiescent galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03412v1.summary: We present elemental abundance patterns (C, N, Mg, Si, Ca, Ti, V, Cr, Fe, Co, Co and Ni) for a population of 135 massive quiescent galaxies at $z\sim0.7$ withultra-deep rest-frame optical spectroscopy. Themajority of elements, as well as the total metallicity and stellar age, show apositive correlation with $\sigma_v$ The highest dispersion galaxies are the earliest and the most metal-rich.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03407v1.title: Identification of tidal features in deep optical galaxy images with Convolutional Neural Networks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03407v1.summary: Interactions between galaxies leave distinguishable imprints which hold important clues about their mass assembly. These structures are difficult to detect because they are low surface brightness features so deep observations are needed. Upcoming surveys promise several orders of magnitude increase in depth and sky coverage, for                which automated methods for tidal feature detection will become mandatory.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03408v1.title: Partial stellar tidal disruption events and their rates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03408v1.summary: Tidal disruption events (TDEs) of stars operated by massive black holes will be detected in thousands by upcoming facilities such as the VeraRubin Observatory. We assess rates of standard total TDEs, destroying the entire star, and partial TDE, in which a stellar remnant                survives the interaction. Our rateestimates are based on a novel definition of the loss cone whose size is commensurate to the largest radius at which partial disruptions can occur.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03952v1.title: An Improved Pair Method to Probe the Dust Extinction Law
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03952v1.summary: Dust extinction law is crucial to recover the intrinsic energy distribution of celestial objects and infer the characteristics of interstellar dust. An improved pair method is proposed to model the dust extinguished spectral energy distribution (SED) of an individual star. The derivedparameters in the dust model can be used to analyze the dust properties, which cannot be achieved by other methods.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04802v1.title: Lopsided Satellite Distributions around Isolated Host Galaxies in a LCDM Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04802v1.summary: A recent observational study found that the projected spatial distributionsof the satellites of bright, isolated host galaxies tend to be lopsided. Here, we examine the spatial distribution of satellites of a large number of host galaxies that were obtained from mock redshift surveys of a LCDM simulation. In agreement with the observational study, we find a strong tendency for satellites in the simulation to be located on the same side of their host.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04790v1.title: Reconciling astronomical distance scales with variable red giant stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04790v1.summary: Stellar standard candles provide the absolute calibration for measuring the Universe's local expansion rate, H0. The accuracy of the H0 measure based on classical Cepheids has been challenged by a measurement based on the Tip of the Red Giant Branch (TRGB) method. This Hubble tension indicates a need forimportant revisions of fundamental physics.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.07865v2.title: COSMOS-Web: An Overview of the JWST Cosmic Origins Survey
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.07865v2.summary: COSMOS-Web is a contiguous 0.54 deg$^2$ NIRCamimaging survey in four filters (F115W, F150w, F277W, and F444W) It will reach 0.19 deg$2$ of MIRI imaging in one filter (F770W) The survey's goals are to discover thousands of galaxies in the Epoch of Reionization.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04726v1.title: PEARLS: Low Stellar Density Galaxies in the El Gordo Cluster Observed with JWST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04726v1.summary: A full understanding of how unusually large "Ultra Diffuse Galaxies" (UDGs) fit into our conventional theory of dwarf galaxy formation remains elusive. A natural extension of UDG research is the study of similar galaxies at higher redshift to establish how their properties may evolve over time.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04717v1.title: Transient obscuration event captured in NGC 3227 IV. Origin of the obscuring cloud variability
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04717v1.summary: Obscuration events in type I active galactic nuclei (AGN) have been detected more frequently in recent years. Another event has been captured in NGC 3227 at the end of 2019. We aim to determine the nature of the observed spectral variability in 2019 obscuration event.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00751v2.title: Clumpy Structures within the Turbulent Primordial Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.00751v2.summary: The first stars in the universe play acrucial role in cosmic evolution. Previous simulations of Pop~III star formation predicted a typical mass of around $100. Recent observations of extremely metal-poor stars suggest a lower mass scale. The mass discrepancy may arise from unresolved turbulence in the Pop~ III star-forming cloud.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04610v1.title: Free-floating or wide-orbit? Keck adaptive-optics observations reveal no host stars near free-floating planet candidates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04610v1.summary: Microlensing events suggest a large population of Earth- to Neptune-mass planets that appear to have no host stars. It is currently unknown whether these objects are truly free-floating planets or whether they are in wide orbits around a distant star. We argue that deeper observations, for example with JWST, are needed to confidently confirm or refute this hypothesis.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04600v1.title: Detecting long-period variability in SDSS Stripe 82 standards catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04600v1.summary: We report the results of a search for long-period ($100<P<600$ days) periodic                variability in SDSS Stripe 82 standards catalog. We present 5. sources with the spectra consistent with quasar spectra and plausible periodic.variability. We use the Kuiper statistic to ensure uniform distribution of data points in phased light curves.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04572v1.title: An Empirical reionization history model inferred from star-forming galaxies at $z>8$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04572v1.summary: We present a new analysis of the rest-frame UV and optical spectra of three $z>8$ galaxies discovered behind the gravitational lensing cluster RX J2129.4+0009. We construct a logistic regression model to estimate the probability of a galaxy being a Lyman continuum emitter. The relative contribution of faint versus bright galaxies depends on redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04528v1.title: The role of magnetic fields in the formation of multiple massive stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04528v1.summary: Magnetic fields are believed to be essential in the accretion andjection processes around single massive protostars. We identify several modes of fragmentation: Toomre-unstable diskfragmentation, arm-arm collision and arm-filament collision. With magnetic fields, the growth of individual disks is regulated even in the absence of fragmentation or truncation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03420v2.title: Parameters of 220 million stars from Gaia BP/RP spectra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.03420v2.summary: We train our model on stellar atmospheric parameters from the LAMOST survey. We model the XP spectra with all of their covariances, augmented by 2MASS and WISE photometry. The modeling procedure alsoproduces an estimate of the optical extinction curve.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08516v2.title: Evidence for globular cluster collapse after a dwarf-dwarf merger: A potential nuclear star cluster in formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08516v2.summary: The dwarf galaxy UGC 7346 is located in the peripheral regions of theirgo Cluster. Its properties indicate the formation of a NSC caught in its earlier stages. The formation of NSCs due to collapse of GCs by dynamical friction in dwarf mergers would provide a natural explanation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01424v2.title: A solar metallicity galaxy at $z >$ 7? Possible detection of the [N II] 122 $μ$m and [O III] 52 $μ$m lines
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01424v2.summary: We present the first detection of the [N II] 122 $m and [O III] 52 $m metrics for a reionisation-epoch galaxy. Based on these lines and previous [C II]158 $m measurements, we estimate an upper limit on electron density of $lesssim$ 500 cm. We also find a gas-phase metallicity of $Z/Z_\odot \sim 1.1 \pm 0.2$ for A1689-zD1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.09945v3.title: Tidal Stripping of a White Dwarf by an Intermediate-Mass Black Hole
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.09945v3.summary: During inspiralling of a white dwarf (WD) into an intermediate-mass blackhole, both gravitational waves (GWs) and electromagnetic(EM) radiation are emitted. Modeling these flares requires a prediction of the amount of stripped mass from the WD and the details of the accretion disk supply. We run hydrodynamical simulations to study the orbital parameter dependence of the stripped mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04377v1.title: Recent updates of gas-phase chemical reactions and molecular lines of SiS in CLOUDY
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04377v1.summary: The spectral synthesis code CLOUDYpredicts SiS line intensities and column densities for various astrophysicalenvironments. As a result, henceforth the code will be used to predict the SiS molecule's energy levels and collisional rate coefficients with H$_2$, H, and He.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04357v1.title: A Survey for High-redshift Gravitationally Lensed Quasars and Close Quasars Pairs. I. the Discoveries of an Intermediately-lensed Quasar and a Kpc-scale Quasar Pair at $z\sim5$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04357v1.summary: We present the first results from a new survey for high-redshift quasars and close quasar pairs. The spectrum of J0025--0145 implies anextreme Eddington ratio if the quasar luminosity is intrinsic, which could be explained by a large lensing magnification.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04243v1.title: Looking for nebular He II emission south of the multiple-massive star system, HD 5980
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04243v1.summary: The nebular He II {\lambda}1640 emission line is observed in star forming                galaxies out to large distances. It can be used to constrain the properties of                sources of He+ ionizing photons. For this purpose, it is crucial to understand which are the main stellar sources of these photons.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04206v1.title: Effects of Magnetic Fields on Gas Dynamics and Star Formation in Nuclear Rings
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04206v1.summary: Nuclear rings at the centers of barred galaxies are known to be strongly magnetic. We explore the effects of magnetic fields on star formation in these rings and nuclear gas flows. We adopt the TIGRESS framework to handle radiative heating and cooling, star formation, and resulting supernova (SN) feedback.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04179v1.title: GN-z11 in context: possible signatures of globular cluster precursors at redshift 10
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04179v1.summary: The first JWST spectroscopy of the luminous galaxy GN-z11 simultaneously both established its redshift at $z=10.6$ and revealed a rest-ultraviolet spectrum dominated by signatures of highly-ionized nitrogen. We definitively establish with a suite of photoionization models that regardless of ionization mechanism and regardless of depletion and this density enhancement, an ISM substantiallyenriched in nitrogen is required to reproduce theobserved lines.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04177v1.title: First Light And Reionisation Epoch Simulations (FLARES) XII: The consequences of star-dust geometry on galaxies in the EoR
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04177v1.summary: Using a realistic star-dust model we explore the consequences of a realistic model on the observed properties of galaxies. We find that the attenuation in the UV luminositydeclines rapidly from the galactic centre. More luminous galaxies have extended star formation that suffers less obscuration than their fainter counterparts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04172v1.title: CO enhancement by magnetohydrodynamic waves; Striations in the Polaris Flare
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04172v1.summary: Magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) waves create compressed quasiperiodic linear structures, referred to as striations. Striations are observed at column densities where the atomic to molecular gastransition takes place. We explore the role of MHD waves in the CO chemistry in regions with striations within molecular clouds.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04171v1.title: The Physical Thickness of Stellar Disks to z ~ 2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04171v1.summary: In local disk galaxies such as our Milky Way, older stars generally inhabit a thicker disk than their younger counterparts. Two competing models have attempted to explain this result. Using legacy HST imagingfrom the CANDELS and GOODS surveys, we measure the rest-optical scale heights of 491 edge-on disk galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04165v1.title: Constraints on Fluctuating Star Formation Rates for Intermediate-mass Galaxies with H$α$ and UV Luminosities
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04165v1.summary: We study the recent star formation histories (SFHs) of 575 intermediate-massgalaxies (IMGs) in COSMOS. We compare their H$\alpha$ and UV luminosities to trace star formation rates (SFRs) on different timescales. The results reveal fluctuations in recent activity.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04157v1.title: Different higher-order kinematics between star-forming and quiescent galaxies based on the SAMI, MAGPI and LEGA-C surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04157v1.summary: We present the first statistical study of spatially integrated non-Gaussianstellar kinematics spanning 7 Gyr in cosmic time. We use deep, rest-frameoptical spectroscopy of massive galaxies at redshifts z = 0.05, 0.3 and 0.8. $h_4$ anti-correlates with the ratio between rotation and dispersion, highlighting the physical connection between these two observables.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04161v1.title: The SAMI Galaxy Survey: Environmental analysis of the orbital structures of passive galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04161v1.summary: Most dynamical models of galaxies to date assume axisymmetry, which is notrepresentative of a significant fraction of massive galaxies. We have built triaxial orbit-superposition Schwarzschild models of the galaxies observed by the SAMI Galaxy Survey. We find that at fixed stellar mass, galaxies in the densest regions are more radiallyanisotropic.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06132v1.title: The extended Planetary Nebula Spectrograph (ePN.S) early-type galaxy survey: The specific angular momentum of ETGs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06132v1.summary: Mass and angular momentum are key parameters of galaxies. This work establishes an empirical relation between the specific stellar angular momentum (j*) and the stellar mass M* that depends on morphology. We measure j* in a sample of 32 early type galaxies (ETGs) from the ePN.S survey.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06115v1.title: Gravitomagnetism and galaxy rotation curves: a cautionary tale
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06115v1.summary: Recent claims that gravitomagnetic effects in linearised general relativity can explain flat and rising rotation curves. We show that for the values of the mass, $M$, typical for a dwarf galaxy, the rotation curve depends only very weakly on $M$. For aspect ratios $a/b > 2$, the rotation curves are concave over their entire range, which does not match observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06107v1.title: The connection between stellar mass, age and quenching timescale in massive quiescent galaxies at $z \simeq 1$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06107v1.summary: We present a spectro-photometric study of a mass-complete sample of quiescent galaxies at $1.0 < z < 1.3$ We explore the relationship between stellar mass, age and star-formation history. We also find a large scatter in the quenching timescales of the VANDELS quiescence galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06083v1.title: Searching for Compact Object Candidates from LAMOST Time-Domain Survey of Four K2 Plates
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06083v1.summary: The study is based on data from the Large Sky Area Multi-Object Fiber Spectroscopic Telescope (LAMOST) It also includes data from K2, ZTF, and TESS surveys. The results suggest that the nature of these six candidates is worth further characterization.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05440v2.title: On the origin of cosmic-ray ionisation in star-forming regions
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05440v2.summary: For starformation to take place, gas and dust need to be sufficiently cold for gravity to overcome thermal pressure. The ionisation fraction must be low enough toenable substantial decoupling between the gas and the Galactic magnetic field. We will briefly focus on the Galactic and local origin of cosmic rays and on their effects on medium ionisation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2110.04434v2.title: The galaxy size to halo spin relation of disk galaxies in cosmological hydrodynamical simulations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2110.04434v2.summary: In the standard disk galaxy formation model, the sizes of galactic disks are tightly related to the spin parameters of their dark matter haloes. However, the size-$\lambda$ correlation was rarely seen in modern hydrodynamical simulations of galaxy formation. In this short paper, we explore the size-spin parameter relation with a large sample of simulated disk galaxies. We conclude that either the detailed subgrid physics or hydrod dynamics solvers account for the relation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04511v4.title: No Need for Extreme Stellar Masses at z~7: A Test-case Study of COS-87259
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.04511v4.summary: Recent controversy regarding the existence of massive (log(M/Msun)>11)galaxies at z>6 poses a challenge for galaxy formation theories. It is of critical importance to understand the effects of SED fitting methods on stellar mass estimates of Epoch of Reionization galaxies. In this work, we perform a case study on the AGN host galaxy candidate COS-87259 with a redshift of 6.853.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05844v1.title: The Mass Distribution of Quasars in Optical Time-domain Surveys
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05844v1.summary: The determination of supermassive black hole (SMBH) masses is the key to understanding the host galaxy build-up. SMBH masses of non-local quasars are frequently estimated via the single-epoch virial black-hole mass estimators, which may suffer from significant biases. Here we demonstrate a new approach to infer the mass distribution of SMB Hs in quasARS by modelling quasar UV/optical variability.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05787v1.title: Distances to 10 nearby galaxies observed with the Hubble space telescope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05787v1.summary: Images of 10 galaxies in F814W and F606W filters obtained on the Hubble SpaceTelescope (HST) are used to construct color-magnitude diagrams for the star populations of these galaxies. The galaxies examined here have radial velocities from 250 to 760 km/s relative to the centroid of the local group.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05743v1.title: Compact Binary Formation in Open Star Clulsters I: High Formation Efficiency of Gaia BHs and Their Multiplicities
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05743v1.summary: Gaia BHs, black hole (BH) binaries discovered from database of an astrometrictelescope Gaia, pose a question to the standard binary evolution model. We have performed gravitational$N$-body simulations of $100$ open clusters with $10^5 M_\odot$ in total for each metallicity $Z=0.02$ and $0.005$ We have discovered one Gaia BH-like binary escaping from an open cluster, and found that the formationefficiency of Gaia Bhs in open clusters is larger than in isolated binaries.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.06042v2.title: Helical dynamo growth at modest versus extreme magnetic Reynolds numbers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.06042v2.summary: We tackle the long-standing question of how much helical large-scale dynamo growth occurs independent of the magnetic Reynolds number(Rm) in a closed volume. From modest-Rm numerical simulations, we identify a pre-saturation regime when the field grows independently of Rm, but with an Rm-dependent magnitude. This gives renewed optimism for the relevance of closed dynamos and pinpoints how modest Rm and hyper-diffusive simulations can cause misapprehension.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.01879v2.title: Estimating Dust Temperature and Far-IR Luminosity of High-Redshift Galaxies using ALMA Single-Band Continuum Observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.01879v2.summary: Using public data from the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) archive, we studied dust temperatures assuming a clumpy interstellar medium (ISM) model for high-redshift galaxies. We find that a dust distribution model assuming a.clumpiness of 1.02\pm0.41 may accurately represent the ISM of high- redshift star-forming galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01006v2.title: Chasing the impact of the Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus merger on the formation of the Milky Way thick disc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.01006v2.summary: We employ our Bayesian Machine Learning framework BINGO to obtain high-quality stellar age estimates for 68,360 red giant and red clump stars. This result is congruent with the chemical evolutioninduced by an early-epoch gas-rich merger identified in the Milky Way-like simulation Auriga. In the initial phase of the merger of Auriga 18 there is a drop in metallicity due to the merger diluting the metal content and an increase in the [Mg/Fe] of the primary galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05645v1.title: Classifying Protoplanetary disks Infrared Spectrum and Analysis by c-C$_3$H$_2$ C$_5$H$_5$ C$_9$H$_7$ C$_{12}$H$_8$ C$_{23}$H$_{12}$ and C$_{53}$H$_{18}$ to be Capable Template for Biological Molecule
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05645v1.summary: Study classified manyastronomically observed infrared spectra of protoplanetary disks to threetypical spectra. Type-A show well known astronomical bands of 6.2, 7.8, 8.6 and 11.3 micrometer. Whereas Type-B included unknown complex bands. Type-(A+B) was mixed type.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.02788v2.title: Polarization fraction of $Planck$ Galactic cold clumps and forecasts for the Simons Observatory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.02788v2.summary: We measure the polarization fraction of a sample of $6282$ Galactic cold clumps. We test if polarization depends on the cold clump's physical properties. The Simons Observatory, with an angular resolution of order $1,000, will significantly enhance our ability to determine the magnetic field structure in cold clumping.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05630v1.title: The Detection of Hot Molecular Cores in the Small Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05630v1.summary: The Small Magellanic Cloud is a nearby dwarf galaxy with 0.2 solar metallicity. We detected emission lines of CO, HCO+, H13CO+, SiO, H2CO, CH3OH, SO, and SO2. Protostellar outflows are also detected from both sources as high-velocity components of CO.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05605v1.title: J1406+0102: Dust Obscured Galaxy Hiding Super Eddington Accretion System with Bright Radio Emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05605v1.summary: Recent high-$z$ quasar observations strongly indicate that super-Eddington accretion is a crucial phase to describe the existence of supermassive blackholes. We show that DOG J1406+0102 is operating strong AGN feedback. Radio-loud DOGs can provide a significant contribution to the high-energy ($\gtrsim$ 100 TeV) cosmic neutrino background.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05603v1.title: The Influence of the Galactic Bar on the Dynamics of Globular Clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05603v1.summary: We make use of recent estimates for the parameters of the Milky Way's halo-globular clusters. We study the influence of the galactic bar on the dynamics of these clusters by computing their orbits. Particular attention is devoted to the Gaia-Sausage/Enceladus and Pontus structures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01895v2.title: Simulating gravitational motion, gas dynamics, and structure in the cosmos
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01895v2.summary: ChaNGa simulates the gravitational motion and gas dynamics of matter in space. We discuss the algorithm for leapfrog integration and smoothed particle hydrodynamics. Problems are provided in order to use ChaNGa to learn or solidify some cosmological concepts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05586v1.title: Gravitational Instability of Gas-Dust Circumnuclear Disks in Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05586v1.summary: We numerically study the origin of the multi-armed spiral structure observed in the circumnuclear gaseous mini-disks of nearby galaxies. We show that the presence of dust in such disks and its interaction with the gravitationallystable Gaseous component leads to the development of a multi-arm spiral structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05574v1.title: The rapid onset of stellar bars in the baryon-dominated centers of disk galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05574v1.summary: JWST observations provide the best evidence to date for mature stellar bars in the redshift range. If baryons dominate over dark matter within $R = R_s$, we predict that a high fraction of bars will be found in high-redshift disks long before 1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05544v1.title: Confirmation of Color Dependent Centroid Shift Measured After 1.8 years with HST
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05544v1.summary: Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope will measure masses using data typically taken within 3-4 years of the peak of the event. This measurement is in agreement with the observation taken in 2005with the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) In 2005 data, the lens and sources were not resolved and the measurement was made using color-dependent centroid shift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05531v1.title: Characterizing the Circumgalactic Medium of Quasars at z $\sim$ 2.2 through H$α$ and Ly$α$ Emission
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05531v1.summary: The discovery of giant quasar Ly$\alpha$ nebulae at $z>2$ has opened up the possibility to directly study in emission the Circumgalactic and IntergalacticMedium (CGM/IGM) However, the resonant nature of the Ly$ \alpha$ line and its different emission mechanisms hamper the ability to constrain the physical properties of the CGM. Here, we present results of a pilot project aiming at the detection of CGM H$\ alpha$ emission, a line which does not suffer from these limitations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05527v1.title: The dark side of FIRE: predicting the population of dark matter subhaloes around Milky Way-mass galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05527v1.summary: We examine 11 Milky Way(MW)-mass haloes from the FIRE-2 baryonic simulations. We compare our results with dark-matter-only versions of the same simulations. Because they lack a central galaxy potential, they overpredict subhalo counts by 2-10x. Our results imply an interaction rate of 5 per Gyr for a stream like GD-1.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05522v1.title: The origin of free-floating planets
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05522v1.summary: Free-floating planets (FFPs) are the lightest products of star formation. They carry important information on the initial conditions of the environment in which they were formed. The JWST will certainly constitute a new step further in the detection andcharacterisation of FFPs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05520v1.title: Evolution in the orbital structure of quiescent galaxies from MAGPI, LEGA-C and SAMI surveys: direct evidence for merger-driven growth over the last 7 Gy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05520v1.summary: We use deep rest-frame optical spectroscopy of quiescent galaxies at redshifts z=0.05, 0.3 and 0.8. We find evidence of $h_4$ increasing with cosmic time. This evolution suggests that, over the last 7 Gyr, there has been a gradual decrease in the rotation-to-dispersion ratio.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05449v1.title: Probing the Global Dust Properties and Cluster Formation Potential of the Giant Molecular Cloud G148.24+00.41
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05449v1.summary: Clouds more massive than about $10^5$ M$_\odot$ are potential sites of massive cluster formation. Studying the properties of such clouds in the early stages of their evolution offers an opportunity to test various clusterformation processes. We make use of CO, Herschel, and UKIDSS observations to study one such cloud, G148.24+00.41.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.00008v2.title: Modeling Supermassive Primordial Stars with MESA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.00008v2.summary: Supermassive stars forming at $z 15 - 20 are one of the leading contenders for the origin of the first quasars. These stars likely form in pristine, atomically cooledhaloes immersed in strong Lyman-Werner UV backgrounds or in highly supersonic baryon streaming flows.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2110.11977v3.title: The SSA22 HI Tomography Survey (SSA22-HIT). I. Data Set and Compiled Redshift Catalog
http://arxiv.org/abs/2110.11977v3.summary: We conducted a deep spectroscopic survey, named SSA22-HIT, on the Keck telescope. 198 galaxies wereSpectroscopically confirmed at 2.5 < z < 6 with a few low-z exceptions. Our data set enables us to make the                HI tomographic map at z > 3.2.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05261v1.title: Rejuvenating infall: a crucial yet overlooked source of mass and angular momentum
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05261v1.summary: Tracer particles allow us to follow the trajectory of accreting material for all protostars. MHD models and the observation of accretion streamers confirmed thatprotostars can undergo late accretion events after the initial collapse phase. Some stars accrete most of their mass during theinitial collapse phase, while others gain >50 % of their final mass from lateAccretion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05200v1.title: Capture of the free-floating planets and primordial black holes into protostellar clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05200v1.summary: The capture of the free-floating planets and primordial black holes into a collapsing protostellar cloud is considered. Capture in the cloud can explain the wide inclinedorbit of the supposed 9th planet in the solar system. At the same time, the probability of primordialblack holes capturing from the galactic halo into acontracting cloud is extremely small.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05184v1.title: Mechanisms of SiO oxidation: Implications for dust formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05184v1.summary: Reactions of SiO molecules have been postulated to initiate efficientformation of silicate dust particles in outflows around dying (AGB) stars. Reactions involving H$_2$O are not efficient routes to oxidation but may under the right conditions lead to hydroxylated species.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05146v1.title: A UNIONS view of the brightest central galaxies of candidate fossil groups
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05146v1.summary: The formation process of fossil groups (FGs) is still under debate. We extracted 87 FG and 100 non-FG candidates from the Tinker spectroscopic catalogue of haloes and galaxies. We made a 2D photometric fit of the BGG with GALFIT with one or two Sersic components and analysed how the subtraction of intracluster light contribution modifies BGG properties.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05104v1.title: Estimating the Oblateness Of Dark Matter Halos Using Neutral Hydrogen Velocity Dispersion
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05104v1.summary: We derive the oblateness parameter q of the dark matter halo of a sample of gas rich, face-on disk galaxies. We have assumed that the halos are triaxial in shape but their axes in the disk plane (a and b) are equal, so that q=c/ameasures the halo flattening. Our most important result is that gas richgalaxies that have M(gas)/M(baryons)>0.5 have oblate halos (q < 0.55)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02365v2.title: Updated measurements of [O III] 88 $μ$m, [C II] 158 $μ$m, and Dust Continuum Emission from a z=7.2 Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.02365v2.summary: We present updated measurements of the [O III] 88 $mu$m, [C II] 158 $mu $m, and dust continuum emission from a star-forming galaxy at $z=7.212$. We combined all the ALMA [OIII] and [CIII] data sets and updated the [C III] detection to $5.9 $mu/m. We also found a strong deficit ($0.6-1.3$ between SXDF-NB1006-2 and the mean $L  [CII]-SFR} relation of galaxies at

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05054v1.title: Are $JWST$/NIRCam color gradients in the lensed $z=2.3$ dusty star-forming galaxy $El~Anzuelo$ due to central dust attenuation or inside-out galaxy growth?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05054v1.summary: The long-wavelength filters of $JWST$'s NIRCam offer a significant step forward. We present an initial analysis of an extraordinary dusty star-forming galaxy (DSFG) at $z=2.3$ behind the $El~Gordo$ cluster. A spatial decomposition of the SED reveals modestly suppressed star formation in the inner kiloparsec.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05051v1.title: The Early Light Curve of a Type Ia Supernova 2021hpr in NGC 3147: Progenitor Constraints with the Companion Interaction Model
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05051v1.summary: The progenitor system of Type Ia supernovae (SNe Ia) is expected to be a carbon/oxygen white dwarf (WD) and a non-degenerate star. Here, we present results from a high-cadence monitoring of SN 2021hpr in a spiral galaxy, NGC 3147.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04572v2.title: An Empirical reionization history model inferred from star-forming galaxies at $z>8$
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04572v2.summary: We present a new analysis of the rest-frame UV and optical spectra of three $z>8$ galaxies discovered behind the gravitational lensing cluster RX J2129.4+0009. We construct a logistic regression model to estimate the probability of a galaxy being a Lyman continuum emitter. The relative contribution of faint versus bright galaxies depends on redshift.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04966v1.title: Infrared Ejecta and Cold Dust in the Young Supernova Remnant N132D
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04966v1.summary: We present Spitzer, WISE, and Herschel observations of the young supernova remnant (SNR) N132D in the LMC. The infrared spectra are remarkablysimilar to those of another young SNR of 1E0102 with Ne and O lines. The IR continuum from the ejecta shows an 18 microns-peak dust feature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04954v1.title: Age-Divided Mean Stellar Populations from Full Spectrum Fitting as the Simplified Star Formation and Chemical Evolution History of a Galaxy: Methodology and Reliability
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04954v1.summary: We introduce a practical methodology for investigating the star formation and chemical evolution history of a galaxy. We generate 10,000 artificial galaxy spectra, each of which consists of five random simple stellar population components. Using the Penalized PiXel-Fitting (pPXF) package, we conduct full spectrumfitting to the artificial spectra with noise as a function of wavelength.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07318v1.title: The Masses of Supernova Remnant Progenitors in M33
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07318v1.summary: We measured the star formation history (SFH) near the position of 85 supernova remnants (SNRs) in M33. We constrained the progenitor masses for 60 of these SNRs. 25 remnants had no local SF in the last 56 Myr consistent with withcore-collapse SNe (CCSNe)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07237v1.title: The atomic-to-molecular hydrogen transition in the TNG50 simulation: Using realistic UV fields to create spatially resolved HI maps
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07237v1.summary: Cold gas in galaxies provides a crucial test to evaluate the realism of cosmological hydrodynamical simulations. To extract the atomic and molecular properties of the simulated galaxy population, postprocessing methods are required. We find discrepancies between WHISP and IllustrisTNG that depend on the total HI abundance in these datasets.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.09393v2.title: The complex interplay of AGN jet-inflated bubbles and the intracluster medium
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.09393v2.summary: We use SWIFT, a smoothed particle hydrodynamics code, to simulate the evolution of bubbles inflated by active galactic nuclei (AGN) jets. Almost all of the energy injected into the jets is transferred to the ICMvery quickly after they are turned off, with roughly $70$ per cent in thermal form and the rest in kinetic.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10263v2.title: First emergence of cold accretion and supermassive star formation in the early universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10263v2.summary: We study the structure of the accretionflow and its evolution within small halos with sufficiently high spatial resolutions. The accretion flow eventually hits a compact disc near the halo centre, creating dense shocks over a wide area of the disc surface. The resulting post-shock gas becomes dense and hot enough with its mass comparable to theJeans mass, leading to the gravitational collapse.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07098v1.title: Spatially resolved observations of outflows in the radio loud AGN of UGC 8782
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07098v1.summary: We use optical Integral Field Spectroscopy (IFU) to study the gas emission structure and kinematics in the inner 3.4 kpc$4.9 kpc region of UGC 8782 (3C 293) The observations were performed with the GMOS-IFU on the Gemini North Americantelescope. Deviations from pure rotation, of up to 20 km s$^{-1}$, are observed in the disc component and likely produced by a previous merger event.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08765v2.title: Model-Independent Mass Reconstruction of the Hubble Frontier Field Clusters with MARS \\ Based on Self-Consistent Strong Lensing Data
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08765v2.summary: We present new strong-lensing (SL) mass reconstruction of the six HubbleFrontier Fields (HFF) clusters with the MAximum-entropy ReconStruction (${\tt                ) algorithm. With $100-200$ multiple images per cluster, we construct solutions with small scatters of multiple images in both source and image planes. We find that in general, these mass pinnacle are in excellent spatial agreement with the member galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06970v1.title: First results from the JWST Early Release Science Program Q3D: Ionization cone, clumpy star formation and shocks in a $z=3$ extremely red quasar host
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06970v1.summary: Massive galaxies formed most actively at redshifts $z=1-3$ during the period known as 'cosmic noon' We use standard emission-line diagnostic ratios to map the sources of gas ionization across the host and a swarm of companion galaxies. The star formation conditions are far moreextreme in these regions than in local star-forming galaxies but consistent with that of massive galaxies at cosmic noon.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06960v1.title: Compressible turbulence in the interstellar medium: New insights from a high-resolution supersonic turbulence simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06960v1.summary: The role of supersonic turbulence in structuring the interstellar medium remains an unsettled question. Here, this problem is investigated using anewexact law of compressible isothermal hydrodynamic turbulence. The law is then used to investigate the properties of such a turbulence at integral Mach number $4$ produced by a massive numerical simulation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11987v2.title: The phase spiral in Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.11987v2.summary: We aim to study the phase spiral in the Milky Way (MW) with Gaia DR3. We find complex variations of the phase spirals withangular momentum and azimuth. All these possibly provide evidence of multipleperturbations (from different times or from different perturbers) and/or of the complexity of the process.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06941v1.title: Radio spectral properties at 150-5000MHz of star-forming galaxies in the ELAIS-N1 field
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06941v1.summary: We combine high-sensitivity LOFAR 150MHz, uGMRT 400MHz, GMRT 610MHz, and JVLA 5GHz data in the ELAIS-N1 field to study the radio spectral properties of star-forming galaxies. We find that, on average, the radio spectrum slightly steepens with increasing stellar mass. We suggest that spectral ageing due to the energy loss of cosmic ray electrons and thermal free-free absorption could be the most likely physical mechanisms that drive the two correlations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09652v2.title: How Ram Pressure Drives Radial Gas Motions in the Surviving Disk
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09652v2.summary: Galaxy evolution can be dramatically affected by the environment, especially by the dense environment of a galaxy cluster. Recent observational studies show that massive galaxies undergoing strong ram pressure stripping (RPS) also show an enhanced frequency of nuclear activity. We find that RPS increases theinflow of gas to the galaxy centre regardless of the wind impact angle.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06866v1.title: Using the Star Forming Main Sequence To Explore Quiescent Galaxies Across Cosmic Time
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06866v1.summary: Low and high-mass galaxies spend the highest fraction of their lives in quiescence. Galaxies of higher mass have fewer quiescent periods, and their length increases withmass. High-mass trends are driven by radio mode feedback from supermassive black holes, which, once active, tend to remain active for extended periods.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.05684v2.title: BICEP / Keck XVI: Characterizing Dust Polarization through Correlations with Neutral Hydrogen
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.05684v2.summary: Dust polarization is important for our understanding of astrophysicalprocesses in the interstellar medium (ISM) and the search for primordial gravitational waves. We characterize Galactic dust filaments by correlating BICEP/Keck and Planck data with polarization templates based on neutral hydrogen (H I) observations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05574v2.title: The rapid onset of stellar bars in the baryon-dominated centers of disk galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.05574v2.summary: Recent observations of high-redshift galactic disks show a negative trend in the dark matter fraction $f_{DM}$ with increasing surface density. Inner baryons must dominate over dark matter in early massive galaxies, as observed in the Milky Way today. We show that stellar bars form promptlywithin these disks, leading to a high bar fraction at early times.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06733v1.title: Probing the Origin of Changing-look Quasar Transitions with Chandra
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06733v1.summary: Extremely variable quasars can also show strong changes in broad line emissions. They are known as Changing Look Quasars (CLQs) We present a pilot sample of CLQs with X-ray Observations both in the bright and faint states. It is highly likely that the observed changes are due to the changing accretion rate of the supermassive black hole.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04717v2.title: Transient obscuration event captured in NGC 3227 IV. Origin of the obscuring cloud variability
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.04717v2.summary: Obscuration events in type I active galactic nuclei (AGN) have been detected more frequently in recent years. Another event has been captured in NGC 3227 at the end of 2019. We aim to determine the nature of the observed spectral variability in 2019 obscuration event.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.01402v4.title: Constraints on galactic outflows from the metallicity-stellar mass-SFR relation of EAGLE simulation and SDSS galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2212.01402v4.summary: Stellar feedback-driven outflows regulate the stellar formation and chemicalenrichment of galaxies. The underlying dependence of mass outflow rate on galaxy properties remains largely unknown. We develop a simple yetcomprehensive non-equilibrium chemical evolution model (NE-CEM) to constrain the mass-loading factor of outflows using the metallicity-stellarmass-SFR relation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06630v1.title: Can gravitational vacuum condensate stars be a dark energy source?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06630v1.summary: Gravitational vacuum condensate stars, also known as gravastars, have been proposed as an alternative to black holes. Their interior contains a perfectfluid with an equation of state akin to that of a cosmological constant. For this reason, they have recently been considered as a possible astrophysicalsource of dark energy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06618v1.title: BUDHIES V: The baryonic Tully-Fisher relation at z=0.2 based on direct HI detections
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06618v1.summary: We present HI-based B- and R-band Tully-Fisher relations (TFRs) and the Baryonic TFR (BTFR) at z=0.2 using direct HI detections from the BlindUltra-Deep HI Environmental Survey (BUDHIES) We compare our results with an identically constructed TFR from the Ursa Major (UMa) association of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06592v1.title: Spatially Resolving PAHs in Herbig Ae Disks with VISIR-NEAR at the VLT
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06592v1.summary: We use the long-slit spectroscopy mode of the VISIR-NEAR experiment to perform diffraction-limited observations of eight nearby Herbig Aeprotoplanetary disks. We observe two kinds of PAH emission geometry in our sample:centrally-peaked (HD 97048) and ring-like (AB Aurigae, HD 100546, HD 163296, and potentially HD 169142) We find a strong correlation in the disk structure but a difference in radial intensity decay rate.

http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.10198v4.title: Chemical modeling for predicting the abundances of certain aldimines and amines in hot cores
http://arxiv.org/abs/1711.10198v4.summary: Methanimine (CH2NH) from CH3N and methylamine ( CH3NH2) were detected a few decades ago. This prompted us to investigate the possibility of detecting any aldimine or amine from the very next three isomeric groups in this sequence. We employ high-level quantum chemical calculations to estimate accurate energies of all species.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06523v1.title: Tidal Disruption Event Demographics with the Zwicky Transient Facility: Volumetric Rates, Luminosity Function, and Implications for the Local Black Hole Mass Function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06523v1.summary: We conduct a systematic tidal disruption event (TDE) demographics analysis using the largest sample of optically selected TDEs. We constrain the optical TDE rate to be [3.7, 7.4, and 10.6$] in galaxies with red, green, and blue colors. We confirm the significant rate suppression at the high-mass end of the event.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06416v1.title: RAD@home discovery of a one-sided radio jet hitting the companion galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06416v1.summary: RAD12 is the first case where the neighbouring galaxy is not a minor or dwarf companion but a galaxy bigger than the host of the radio jet. The jet appears to be one-sided and the jet after interaction completely stops and forms a bubble inflating laterally. More discovery of objects like RAD12 will be important to the understanding of galaxy evolution through merger and AGN feedback.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06393v1.title: New features of the Gaia phase spiral and its possible relation to internal perturbations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06393v1.summary: The data reveal a two-armedphase spiral pattern in the local $z-v_z$ plane inside the solar radius. The pattern is characteristic of a breathing mode that can in principle be produced by non-axisymmetric perturbations. We conclude that a time-varying strong internal perturbation together with an external verticalperturbation could perhaps explain the transition between the two-arm and one-armed phase-spirals around the Solar radius.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06328v1.title: Probing the Nature of the First Galaxies with JWST and ALMA
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06328v1.summary: Using a model of primordial dust emission, we predict dust-continuum fluxes for massive galaxy sources. Current upper flux limits, obtained with ALMA for some of these sources, can constrain gas metallicity and dust fraction of the first galaxies. Such low $D/M$ values and metallicities are in agreement with some scenarios proposed in the literature to explain the non-detection of the FIR dust continuum.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06249v1.title: A declining major merger fraction with redshift in the local Universe from the largest-yet catalog of major and minor mergers in SDSS
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06249v1.summary: It is difficult to accurately identify galaxy mergers. We present the probability that each galaxy is a major or minor merger. We measure the major and minor merger fraction. We bin as a function of stellar mass and redshift. We determine that the positive trend of the major merger fraction with stellar mass is consistent with a hierarchicalassembly scenario.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06191v1.title: Detection of wide binary and multiple nuclei of planetary nebulae using the Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06191v1.summary: This paper describes the detection of wide binary and multiplecentral stars (CSs) of Galactic planetary nebulae (PNe) Using the most up-to-date data available from the Gaia Data Release 3 (Gaia DR3), we have detected a total of 45 binary andMultiple stellar systems. The results further show that the primary components of eight wide and very wide binary systems are actually close binary systems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07896v2.title: The Kormendy relation of early-type galaxies as a function of wavelength in Abell S1063, MACS J0416.1-2403, and MACS J1149.5+2223
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.07896v2.summary: The Kormendy relation (KR) is well characterised at low redshift but poorly studied at intermediate redshifts. The KR provides information on the evolution of the population of early-type galaxies. By studying it, we may shed light on the assembly processes of theseobjects and their size evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06175v1.title: The LMC impact on the kinematics of the Milky Way satellites: clues from the running solar apex
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.06175v1.summary: Dwarf galaxies provide a unique opportunity for studying the evolution of the Milky Way and the Local Group as a whole. Analysing the running solar apex of the MW satellites, we discovered an unexpectedbehaviour of the dipole term of the radial velocity distribution as a function of the galactocentric distance.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11324v3.title: The AGNIFS survey: spatially resolved observations of hot molecular and ionised outflows in nearby active galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.11324v3.summary: We present the hot molecular and warm ionised gas kinematics for 33 nearby galaxies. We find that 31 objects (94 per cent) present a kinematically disturbed region (KDR) seen in Ionised gas. Such regions are observed in hot molecular gas for 76 per cent of galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08088v1.title: How Cosmic Web Environment Affects Galaxy Quenching Across Cosmic Time
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08088v1.summary: We investigate how cosmic web structures affect galaxy quenching in the IllustrisTNG (TNG-100) cosmological simulations. We measure the distance from each galaxy with stellar mass log(M*/Msun)>=8 to the nearest node (dnode) and the nearest filament spine (dfil) We study the dependence of both median specific star formation rate (sSFR) and median gas fraction (fgas) on these distances.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08087v1.title: Search strategies for supermassive stars in young clusters and application to nearby galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08087v1.summary: Supermassive stars (SMS) are formed by runaway collisions in young, massive, and dense star clusters. SMS are thought to be the precursors of globular clusters, GCs. We used theoretical predictions of SMS and SMS-hosting clusters to examine their impact on color-color diagrams and individual optical spectral lines.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08056v1.title: Very metal-poor stars in the solar vicinity: kinematics and abundance analysis
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08056v1.summary: Very metal-poor stars contain crucial information on the Milky Way's infancy. We did not find any Al-Mg anti-correlation, which lead us to the conclusion that these stars did not form in globular clusters. These stars are most probably associated with the pristine Bulge. We sketch a scenario for theformation of the Milkyway in which the first structure to form was the Bulge through rapid collapse.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.16652v6.title: The diversity of rotation curves of simulated galaxies with cusps and cores
http://arxiv.org/abs/2203.16652v6.summary: We use cosmological hydrodynamical simulations to explore thekinematics of gaseous discs in late-type dwarf galaxies. We create high-resolution 21-cm 'observations' of simulated dwarfs produced in twovariations of the EAGLE galaxy formation model. We find systematic discrepancies between the recovered rotation curve and the actual circular velocity curve.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08024v1.title: Starbursts in low-mass haloes at Cosmic Dawn. I. The critical halo mass for star formation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08024v1.summary: First stars, galaxies, star clusters, and direct-collapse black holes areexpected to have formed in low-mass haloes at Cosmic Dawn. The halo mass cooling threshold has been analyzed by several authors using both analytical models and numerical simulations, with differing results. In this paper the cooling threshold mass is calculatedanalytically, considering the effects of H$_2$-cooling and formation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.04709v4.title: EMPRESS. IX. Extremely Metal-Poor Galaxies are Very Gas-Rich Dispersion-Dominated Systems: Will JWST Witness Gaseous Turbulent High-z Primordial Galaxies?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2206.04709v4.summary: We present kinematics of 6 local extremely metal-poor galaxies (EMPGs) with low stellar masses. All the EMPGs show rotational velocities of 5--23 km s$^{-1}$ smaller than the velocity dispersions. This suggests they are dispersion-dominated systems affected by inflow and/or outflow.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07955v1.title: N-enhancement in GN-z11: First evidence for supermassive stars nucleosynthesis in proto-globular clusters-like conditions at high redshift ?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07955v1.summary: Unusually high N/O abundances were recently reported for a very compact,intensively star-forming object GN-z11 at z=10.6 from JWST/NIRSpecobservations. This suggests that a proto-globular cluster hosting a SMS could be at the origin of the strong N-enrichment.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07943v1.title: SKA Science Data Challenge 2: analysis and results
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07943v1.summary: The Square Kilometre Array Observatory (SKAO) will explore the radio sky to new depths in order to conduct transformational science. SKAO data products will be correspondingly large and complex, requiring advanced analysis techniques to extract key findings. To this end, SKaO is conducting a series of Science DataChallenges, each designed to familiarise the scientific community.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07931v1.title: The ionising photon production efficiency at z~6 for a sample of bright Lyman-alpha emitters using JEMS and MUSE
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07931v1.summary: We study the ionising photon production efficiency at the end of the Epoch of Reionisation. We exploit observations from the JWST Advanced Deep Extragalactic Survey (JADES) to find the flux excess corresponding to the redshifted \ha\ emission line. We estimate the UV luminosity by fitting the full JEMS photometry, along with several HST photometric points.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10779v3.title: MusE GAs FLOw and Wind (MEGAFLOW) IX. The impact of gas flows on the relations between the mass, star formation rate and metallicity of galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.10779v3.summary: We study the link between gas flow events and key galaxy scaling relations. Using all star-forming galaxies (SFGs) in the 22 MUSE fields of the MusE GAs FLOw and Wind survey, we derive the MS, MZR and FMRscaling relations for 385 SFGs. Our observations support the scenario in which gas accretion increases the SFR while diluting the metal content.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07827v1.title: Formation of supermassive stars in the first star clusters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07827v1.summary: Formation of supermassive stars is believed to be an essential step for the formation of the massive black hole seeds that become supermassive black holes. Numerical simulations have shown that supermassive. stars can form inatomic-cooling halos when protostars reach accretion rates higher than. $N$-body plus hydrodynamical simulations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.13250v2.title: Spectrally resolved cosmic rays: II -- Momentum-dependent cosmic ray diffusion drives powerful galactic winds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2109.13250v2.summary: cosmic ray (CR) feedback has been identified as a critical process in galaxy formation. The spectral model for the CRs enables more accurate cooling of CRs and allows for an energy-dependent spatial diffusion. The shapes of the approximate steady state spectradiffer for individual regions of the galaxy, which highlights the importance of including the full CR spectrum.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07752v1.title: The enhanced YSO population in Serpens
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07752v1.summary: The Serpens Molecular Cloud is one of the most active sites of ongoing starforming at a distance of about 300 pc. We find potential members of the Young StellarObjects population from the Gaia DR3 data and study their kinematics and distribution. We also classified these objects using 2MASS and WISE data to study their distribution and the progress of starforming.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07741v1.title: Introduction to Faraday tomography and its future prospects
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07741v1.summary: Faraday tomography is a new method of the study of cosmic magnetic fields. It is enabled by broadband low-frequency radio observations. The Faraday dispersion function contains information on the line-of-sight distributions of magnetic fields, thermal-electron density, and cosmic-ray electron density. In this review, we explain the basics of FaradayTomography with simple and instructive examples.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.13860v3.title: Early results from GLASS-JWST XVI: Discovering a bluer z~4-7 Universe through UV slopes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.13860v3.summary: We use the GLASS-JWST Early Release Science NIRCam parallel observations to provide a first view of the UV continuum properties of selected galaxies. We find that >99% of the galaxies are blue star-forming galaxies with very low levels of dust (Avbeta~0.01+/-0.33). We find no statistically significant correlation for UV slope with redshift or UV vehementlymagnitude.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08259v2.title: A new limit on intergalactic magnetic fields on sub-kpc scales from fast radio bursts
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.08259v2.summary: We use the measured scattering timescales of Fast Radio Bursts (FRBs) to derive an upper limit on the magnetic field on sub-kpcscales in the intergalactic medium (IGM) A nonmagnetized, photoionized IGM is insufficient to explain the turbulent scattering at all redshifts.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07639v1.title: The Role of Outflow Feedback on Accretion of Compact Objects in Accretion Disk of Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07639v1.summary: Compact objects (COs) can exist and evolve in an active galactic nuclei (AGN) disk. This triggers a series of attractive CO-related multi-messenger events around a supermassive black hole. In this paper, we study the specific accretion process of a CO in an AGN disk and explore the role of outflow feedback.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07628v1.title: Magnetic fields in the Horsehead Nebula
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07628v1.summary: The Horsehead Nebula contains two sub-millimeter sources, a photodissociationregion (PDR; SMM1) and a starless core (SMM2) We see well-ordered magnetic Fields in both sources. The magnetic fields appear to currently play an important role in supporting both sources, and suggest a schematic view of their structure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07619v1.title: Observational Evidence for Large-Scale Gas Heating in a Galaxy Protocluster at z=2.30
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07619v1.summary: We report a $z=2.30$ galaxy protocluster (COSTCO-I) in the COSMOS field. The Lyman-$\alpha$ forest as seen in the CLAMATO IGM tomography survey does not show significant absorption. This departs from the transmission-density relationship (often dubbed the fluctuating Gunn-Petersonapproximation; FGPA)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07590v1.title: The physical origin of super-competitive accretion during the formation of the first supermassive black holes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07590v1.summary: Numerical simulations have shown the occurence of a scenario termed ''super-competitive accretion'', a term that describes a situation where only the central few objects grow supermassive while a larger number of stars compete for the reservoir. This scenario particularly implies that the presence offragmentation will not necessarily impeed the formation of a central massive object.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07554v1.title: Zwicky Transient Facility and Globular Clusters: The Period-Luminosity and Period-Wesenheit Relations for SX Phoenicis Variables in the gri-Band
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07554v1.summary: SX Phoenicis (SXP) variables are short period pulsating stars that exhibit aperiod-luminosity (PL) relation. We derived the gri-band PL and extinction-freeperiod-Wesenheit (PW) relations, as well as the period-color (PC) and period-Q-index (PQ) relations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07549v1.title: VERTICO V: The environmentally driven evolution of the inner cold gas discs of Virgo cluster galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07549v1.summary: The quenching of cluster satellite galaxies is inextricably linked to the suppression of their cold interstellar medium (ISM) While the removal of neutral atomic hydrogen (HI) at large radii is well studied, how the environment impacts the remaining gas in the centres of                galaxies is less clear.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03313v2.title: Universal scaling laws and density slope for dark matter haloes
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.03313v2.summary: Energy cascade from small to large scales with a constant rate is a fundamental feature of dark matter flow. The largest halo scale $r_l$ can be determined by $-u_0^3/\varepsilon_u$ The smallestscale $r_{\eta}$ is dependent on the nature of dark Matter.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07513v1.title: The Extended [CII] under Construction? Observation of the brightest high-z lensed star-forming galaxy at z = 6.2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07513v1.summary: We find that MACS0308-zD1's star-formation activity occurs in a dust-free environment with stringent upper limit of infrared luminosity. Targeting this strongly lensed faint galaxy for follow-up ALMA and JWST observations will be crucial to characterize the details of typical galaxy growth in the early Universe.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09540v2.title: Aligning Retrograde Nuclear Cluster Orbits with an Active Galactic Nucleus Accretion Disc
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.09540v2.summary: Stars and stellar remnants orbiting a supermassive black hole (SMBH) can interactions with an active galactic nucleus (AGN) disc. Captured stars can be tidally disrupted by sBH or rapidly grow into massive 'immortal' stars. We show that retrograde stars are captured faster than prograde stars, flip to prograde and decrease $a$ dramatically towards the SMBH. Whether a star is captured by the disc within an AGN lifetime depends primarily on disc density.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07501v1.title: High-Mass Starless Clumps: Dynamical State and Correlation Between Physical Parameters
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07501v1.summary: We have previously built a sample of 463 high-mass starless clumps (HMSCs) across theinner Galactic plane covered by multiple continuum surveys. Here, we use CO(2-1) line data from the SEDIGISM survey to investigate the global dynamical state of HMSCs. We find that most HMSCs are highly turbulent with a median Mach number of 8.2, and 55% are gravitationally bound.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07448v1.title: Kinematics, Structure, and Mass Outflow Rates of Extreme Starburst Galactic Outflows
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07448v1.summary: Using optical Keck/HIRES spectroscopy of 14 HizEAstarburst galaxies we identify outflows with maximum velocities of $820 - 2860$ kmps.
