We find substantial variation in the absorption profiles, which likely reflects the complex morphology of inhomogeneously-distributed, clumpy gas.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07422v1.title: A variable star population in the open cluster NGC 6791 observed by the Kepler spacecraft
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07422v1.summary: We present the list of variable stars we found in the Kepler superstamp data                covering approximately 9 arcminutes from the central region of NGC 6791. In total we found278 variable objects, among which 17 binaries, 45 pulsators, 62 rotational and five unclassified variables are cluster members. Only three objects show significant orbital period fluctuations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07419v1.title: Mapping the Decline with Redshift of Dusty Star-forming Galaxies Using JWST and SCUBA-2
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07419v1.summary: We use JWST NIRCam observations from 1.5 to 4.44 micron of the massive Lensing cluster field A2744. We show that there is a strong drop (a factor of around 5) in the ratio of the far-infrared luminosity to the bolometric luminosity at therest-frame 5000 A between z<4 and z>4.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07410v1.title: Relative Alignment Between Magnetic Fields and Molecular Gas Structure in Molecular Clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07410v1.summary: We compare the structure of synthetic dust polarization with syntheticmolecular line emission from radiative transfer calculations using a turbulent collapsing-cloud magnetohydrodynamics simulation. We find good agreement between these results and sub-Alfv\'enic simulations when viewed with the magnetic field in the plane of the sky.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07387v1.title: Searching for the sources of excess extragalactic dispersion of FRBs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07387v1.summary: The FLIMFLAM survey is collecting spectroscopic data of field galaxies near fast radio burst (FRB) sightlines to constrain key parameters describing the distribution of matter in the Universe. In this work, we leverage the survey data to determine the source of the excess extragalactic dispersion measure(DM)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07378v1.title: Dark-ages reionization and galaxy formation simulation -- XXI. Constraining the evolution of the ionizing escape fraction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07378v1.summary: The fraction of ionizing photons that escape their host galaxies to ionizeHydrogen in the inter-galactic medium (IGM) is a critical parameter in analyses of the reionization era. In this paper we use the Meraxes semi-analytic galaxyformation model to infer the mean ionizing photon escape fraction and its dependence on galaxy properties. As a function of redshift, we find that reionizing is dominated by the smaller galaxies with high escape fractions.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07376v1.title: Metal Factories in the Early Universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07376v1.summary: We measured the mass of metals in 13 submillimetre galaxies at z~4 in which the gas, based on previous observations, lies in a cold rotating disk. We used the dynamical masses of these galaxies to set an upper limit on the metal abundance of the interstellar medium. Using two chemical evolution models, we show that the high metal masses and metal abundances are what is expected shortly after the formation of a top-heavy IMF.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07375v1.title: On the Tidal Capture of White Dwarfs by Intermediate-mass Black Holes in Dense Stellar Environments
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07375v1.summary: intermediate-mass black holes (IMBHs) are the missing link betweenstellar-mass and supermassive black holes. Tidaldisruptions of white dwarfs (WDs) provide a unique smoking gunthat could finally probe the existence of IMBH's beyond any reasonable doubt.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07369v1.title: Updated radial velocities and new constraints on the nature of the unseen source in NGC1850 BH1
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.07369v1.summary: A black hole candidate orbiting a luminous star in the Large Magellanic Cloud cluster NGC 1850 ($\sim100$Myr) has recently been reported. An alternative explanation has been suggested for the system: a bloated post-mass transfer star with a more massive, yet luminous companion.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10141v1.title: An HI story of galaxies in Abell 2626 and beyond
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10141v1.summary: The HI deficiency of a galaxy is strongly correlated with the projected distance from the centre of A2626. The substructure galaxies tend to be more asymmetric than the isolated galaxies in the cluster. galaxies in all three environments have slightly lower star-formation rates than the typical SFR for normal galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10115v1.title: 3D hydrodynamics simulations of core convection in supermassive main-sequence stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10115v1.summary: Supermassive stars could be the progenitors of the first supermassive blackholes. Their interiors are in a regime where radiation pressure dominates theequation of state. We conclude that the radiation pressure-dominated nature of the star's interior does not noticeably affect the behaviour of convection.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10099v1.title: Reconstructing Galactic magnetic fields from local measurements for backtracking ultra-high-energy cosmic rays
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10099v1.summary: Ultra-high energy cosmic rays (UHECRs) are highly energetic particles with energies exceeding $10^{18}$ eV. Identifying their sources and production mechanism can provide insight into many open questions in astrophysics and high energy physics. The Galactic magnetic field (GMF) deflects UHECR, and the high uncertainties in our current understanding of the $3$-dimensional structure of the GMF does not permit us to accurately determine their true arrival direction.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10077v1.title: Galaxy And Mass Assembly (GAMA): Bulge-disk decomposition of KiDS and VIKING data in the nearby universe
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10077v1.summary: This thesis presents a catalogue of robust structural parameters for the components of nearby GAMA galaxies. The sample consists of 13096 galaxies at redshifts z < 0.08 with imaging data from the Kilo-Degree Survey and VISTA INfrared Galaxy survey. We fit three models to the surface brightness distribution of each galaxy in each band.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16532v2.title: Merger Signatures are Common, but not Universal, In Massive, Recently-Quenched Galaxies at z~0.7
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.16532v2.summary: We present visual classifications of merger-induced tidal disturbances in 143 post-starburst galaxies at z$\sim$0.7identified. This sample spectroscopicallyselects galaxies from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey that have stopped their primary epoch of star formation within the past $500 Myrs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10013v1.title: Star-formation rate and stellar mass calibrations based on infrared photometry and their dependence on stellar population age and extinction
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.10013v1.summary: The stellar mass ($M_\star$) and the star-formation rate (SFR) are among the most important features that characterize galaxies. Measuring these fundamentalproperties accurately is critical for understanding the present state of galaxies. This work explores the dependence of the IRemission of galaxies on their extinction, and the age of their stellar populations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09926v1.title: StarHorse results for spectroscopic surveys + Gaia DR3: Chrono-chemical populations in the solar vicinity, the genuine thick disk, and young-alpha rich stars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09926v1.summary: The Gaia mission has provided an invaluable wealth of astrometric data for more than a billion stars in our Galaxy. Using the Bayesian isochrone-fitting code StarHorse, we derive distances and extinctions for 10 million unique stars observed by Gaia. We identify three distinct groups in all three samples. Theirkinematic properties confirm them to be the genuine chemical thick disk.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.11196v2.title: The XXL Survey L. Active galactic nucleus contamination in galaxy clusters: Detection and cosmological impact
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.11196v2.summary: X-ray observations of galaxy clusters are impacted by the presence of active galaxies (AGNs) in a manner that is challenging to quantify. The majority of these systems are otherwise missed by current X-ray cluster-detection methods. We introduce a new automated class for AGN-contaminated (AC)centricclusters in the XXL source detection pipeline.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.17507v2.title: The effects of Time-Variable Absorption due to Gamma-Ray Bursts In Active Galactic Nuclei Accretion Disks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.17507v2.summary: Both long and short gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are expected to occur in the dense environments of active galactic nuclei (AGN) accretion disks. As these bursts propagate through the disks they live in, they photoionize the medium causing time-dependent opacity that results in transients with unique spectral evolution.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.00604v2.title: Tidal Stripping in the Adiabatic Limit
http://arxiv.org/abs/2207.00604v2.summary: We present a model for the remnants of haloes that have gone through anadiabatic tidal stripping process. We show that this model exactly reproducesthe remnant of an NFW halo that is exposed to a slowly increasing isotropictidal field and approximately for an anisotropic tidal field. The model can be used to predict the asymptotic mass loss limit for orbiting subhaloes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09883v1.title: On the propagation of Alfvén waves in the dusty interstellar medium. Can we neglect dust inertia in molecular clouds?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09883v1.summary: Alfv\'en waves are fundamental magnetized modes which play an important role in the dynamics of magnetized flows such as the interstellar medium (ISM) Yet, in most calculations, for numerical reasons, the grain inertia is usually neglected. We investigate analytically the propagation of Alfv \'en waves both in a single-size and multi-size grain medium.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.08103v2.title: The need for obscured supermassive black hole growth to explain quasar proximity zones in the epoch of reionization
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.08103v2.summary: Proximity zones of high-redshift quasars are unique probes of supermassive black hole formation. But explaining proximity zone sizes and black hole masses has proved to be challenging. We show that small proximity zones can be readilyexplained by quasARS that vary in brightness with a short duty cycle.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09845v1.title: The `blazar sequence' in TeV band
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09845v1.summary: The `blazar sequence' has been proposed for more than 20 years, yet itsnature is still unclear. In this work, for the first time, we expand this topic to the TeV band by using a sample of 58 TeV blazars. We find the blazar sequence is shown in the flaring state rather than in the quiescent state.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09783v1.title: WIYN Open Cluster Study 89. M48 (NGC 2548) 2: Lithium Abundances in the 420 Myr Open Cluster M48 From Giants Through K Dwarfs
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09783v1.summary: Li-Teff trends of the Li Dip (6675-6200K), Li Plateau (6200-6000K), and G and K dwarfs (6000-4000K) are very clearly delineated. Early F dwarfs already show evidence of Li depletion seen in older clusters. Forlate-G/K dwarfs, faster rotators show higher Li than slower rotators.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09726v1.title: The Emergence of Brightest Cluster Galaxy in the Most Massive Protocluster Core
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09726v1.summary: A pair of massive quiescent galaxies are likely in the process of merging at the centre of the spectroscopicallyconfirmed, extremely massive protocluster BOSS1244. The galaxies were detected with HubbleSpace Telescope (HST) grism slitless spectroscopic observations. These two galaxies are among the brightest member galaxies in the cluster and are separated by about 70 physicalkiloparsecs.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09712v1.title: A catalog of nearby accelerating star candidates in Gaia DR3
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09712v1.summary: New catalog of accelerating star candidates with Gaia. Designated as Gaia Nearby AcceleratingStar Catalog (GNASC) It contains 29,684 members identified using a supervisedmachine-learning algorithm. Test data suggest catalog members each have a 68% likelihood of true astrometric accelerating.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09637v1.title: Origin of the diffuse 4-8 keV emission in M82
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09637v1.summary: X-ray spectroscopic study of the 4-8 keV diffuse emission found in the central part of the nearby starburst galaxy. The Fexxv emission at 6.7 keV is enhanced only in a limited area close to the starburst disc. This shows the presence of non-thermal emission due to inverse Compton scattering.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08336v2.title: CMR exploration I -- filament structure with synthetic observations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.08336v2.summary: We explore the collision-induced magnetic reconnection (CMR) mechanism that forms filamentarymolecular clouds. Athena++ is used to model CMR in the context of resistive magnetohydrodynamics. We quantify the results with five metrics, including the density probability and dominant fiber width. Overall, the exploration provides useful initial insights to the CMR mechanism.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02675v2.title: Symphony: Cosmological Zoom-in Simulation Suites over Four Decades of Host Halo Mass
http://arxiv.org/abs/2209.02675v2.summary: We present Symphony, a compilation of $262$ cosmological, cold-dark-matter-only zoom-in simulations spanning four decades of host halomass. The highest-resolution regions in these simulations are resolved with a dark matter particle mass of 3 times host virial mass. We demonstrate that these predictions successfully resolve the formation histories of the halos that host nearly all currentlyobservable satellite galaxies.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09583v1.title: Can we observe the ion-neutral drift velocity in prestellar cores?
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09583v1.summary: Ambipolar diffusion is thought to be an integral process in star formation. The ion-neutral drift velocity is inherently very small. The coldest modelled cores exhibited drift velocities comparable to the sound speed. In idealized scenarios, the drift velocity survives radiative transfer effects and can in principle be observed.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09574v1.title: 3D Radiative Transfer Modelling and Virial Analysis of Starless Cores in the B10 Region of the Taurus Molecular Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09574v1.summary: New observations at 1.2mm and 2.0mm with the NIKA2 instrument on the IRAM 30m have probed theinner regions of 14 low-mass starless cores. We find 9 out of the 14 cores ($64\%$) are either in virialophobicequilibrium or are bound by gravity and external pressure.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09570v1.title: CLEAR: Survey Overview, Data Analysis and Products
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09570v1.summary: We present an overview of the CANDELS Lyman-a Emission At Reionization(CLEAR) survey. CLEAR is a 130 orbit program of the Hubble Space Telescope using the Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) IR G102 grism. In this Paper, we describe the CLEAR survey, the survey strategy, the data acquisition, reduction, and processing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09568v1.title: RXJ0437+00: Constraining Dark Matter with Exotic Gravitational Lenses
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09568v1.summary: The galaxies lensed by RXJ0437 are magnified by factors ranging from 30 to 300. The H-U images are located only 20 -- 50 kpc from the galaxy cluster's centre. These systems are able to constrain the inner slope of the mass distribution. They can be used to probe for small-scale ($\sim 10^{9} M_\odot}$substructures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09569v1.title: Multimessenger study of merging massive black holes in the Obelisk simulation: gravitational waves, electromagnetic counterparts, and their link to galaxy and black hole populations
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09569v1.summary: Massive black hole (BH) mergers are predicted to be powerful sources of low-frequency gravitational waves (GWs) Coupling the detection of GWs withelectromagnetic (EM) detection can provide key information about merging BHs and their environments.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01345v2.title: The MUSE Ultra Deep Field (MUDF). III. Hubble Space Telescope WFC3 Grism Spectroscopy and Imaging
http://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01345v2.summary: We present extremely deep Hubble Space Telescope (HST) Wide Field Camera 3 (WFC3) observations of the MUSE Ultra Deep Field (MUDF) This unique region of the sky contains two quasars at $z \approx$ 3.22 that are separated by only 500 kpc. We have obtained 90 orbits of HST WFC3 G141 near-infrared grism spectroscopy of this field.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2111.13708v2.title: How baryons affect halos and large-scale structure: a unified picture from the Simba simulation
http://arxiv.org/abs/2111.13708v2.summary: The main physical drivers shaping the distribution of matter at all scales are star formation-driven galacticoutflows and AGN jets. 87% of the baryonic mass in the Universe lies in the IGM at $z=0$, with 67% being in the form of warm-hot IGM.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09473v1.title: Molecular gas in super spiral galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09473v1.summary: Only a small fraction of galaxies are disk-like and actively star-forming objects. These so-called 'super spirals' are ideal objects to better understand how galaxy evolution proceeds. We analyze their molecular gas mass in relation to their star formation rate (SFR) and stellar mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09425v1.title: Velocity measurement in the extensive [OIII] emission region 1.2° south-east of M31
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09425v1.summary: The discovery of a broad, $\sim$1.5$^{\circ}$ long filamentary [OIII] 5007emission south-east of the M31 nucleus has recently beenreported. More than 100 hours of exposures of a wide field have allowed this pioneering detection based on 30 narrow-band filters and several small refractors.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09391v1.title: Rapidly growing primordial black holes as seeds of the massive high-redshift JWST Galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09391v1.summary: A group of massive galaxies at redshifts of $z\geq 6.5$ have been recently discovered by James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) The formation of some primordial black holes (PBHs) formed in the early Universe via super-Eddington accretion within the dark matter halo can explain these observations. These PBHs may act as seeds for early galaxies formation with masses of $\sim 10^{9}-10^{10}~M_\odot$ at redshift 8.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09374v1.title: Extinction towards the cluster R136 in the Large Magellanic Cloud: An extinction law from the near-infrared to the ultraviolet
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09374v1.summary: The cluster R136 in the giant star-forming region 30 Doradus in the Large                Magellanic Cloud (LMC) offers a unique opportunity to resolve a stellarpopulation in a starburst-like environment. We obtain the near-infrared to ultraviolet extinction towards 50 stars in the core of R136, employing the 'extinction without standards' method.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09371v1.title: MIGHTEE-\HI: Possible interactions with the galaxy NGC~895
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09371v1.summary: The galaxy NGC~895 was previously thought to be isolated. High-sensitivity observations from the MeerKAT large survey project MIGHTEE reveal possible interactions. NGC 895 is an actively star-forming galaxy with a SFR of 1.75.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.02822v2.title: An empirical approach to selecting the first growing black hole seeds with JWST/NIRCam
http://arxiv.org/abs/2208.02822v2.summary: The James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) will have the sensitivity to detect early low-mass black holes. Based on the JAGUAR mock catalog of galaxies, we present a clean color selection that takes advantage of the unique UV slope of accreting supermassive black holes with relatively low mass and high accretion rates.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.12978v3.title: On the gravitational lensing interpretation of three gravitational wave detections in the mass gap by LIGO and Virgo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2204.12978v3.summary: Gravitational lensing delays the arrival of gravitational waves, and alters their amplitude. This would provide a physically well-understoodinterpretation of GW detections in the ''mass gap'' between neutron stars and black holes. LIGO-Virgo's third run found three GWs that may have been affected by gravitational lensing.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09284v1.title: Exploring dark matter spike distribution around the Galactic centre with stellar orbits
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09284v1.summary: Precise measurements of the stellar orbits around Sagittarius A* have established the existence of a supermassive black hole (SMBH) at the Galactic center. Due to the interplay between the SMBH and dark matter, the DMdensity profile in the innermost region of the Galaxy is still an open question. We examine the radius and slope of the generalized NFW spike profile, analyze the Einasto spike, and discuss the influence of DM annihilation.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09947v2.title: High-resolution Imaging of Two Radio Quasars at the End of the Reionization Epoch
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.09947v2.summary: There are approximately 250 quasars discovered at redshift $z\geq6$, of which only a handful were detected in radio bands. Even fewer were imaged with the highest resolution very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) technique. Our VLBAobservations revealed a flat-spectrum compact radio source. The latter has an UV/optical spectrum characteristic of BL Lacobjects.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09263v1.title: Radio and mid-infrared properties of the blazar J1419$-$0838
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09263v1.summary: The radio quasar NVSS J141922$-$083830 was initiallyclassified as an uncategorised blazar-type object. Later, using observations and modeling, its was found to be a flat-spectrumradio quasar (FSRQ) Its radio emission has never been discussed in sufficientlydepth in the literature.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09259v1.title: The Origin of the Large Magellanic Cloud Globular Cluster NGC 2005
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09259v1.summary: The ancient Large Magellanic Cloud (LMC) globular cluster NGC 2005 has reportedly been reported to have an ex-situ origin. The LMC could have partially formed from smaller merged dwarf galaxies. The present analysis points to the need for further development of numerical simulations and observational indices.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08795v2.title: Rapidly evolving Galactic plane outbursts in NEOWISE: Revisiting the Galactic nova rate with the first all-sky search in the mid-infrared
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08795v2.summary: The Galactic nova rate is intimately linked to our understanding of its chemical enrichment and progenitor channels of Type Ia supernovae. Pastestimates have varied by more than an order of magnitude. Using 8 years of data from the NEOWISE mid-infrared survey, we identify 49 candidate Galactic novae.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09246v1.title: Correlation analysis between several observables of OJ 287 radio jet
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09246v1.summary: We collected the archival data of blazar OJ~287 from heterogeneous very long baseline interferometry (VLBI) monitoring programs at 2.3 GHz, 8.6 GHz, 15 GHz and 43 GHz. We employ the cross-correlation function to search the correlations and the Monte Carlo technique to verify the certainty of correlations.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12689v2.title: Theory and phenomenology of stressed wave-dark-matter soliton
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.12689v2.summary: Soliton in the hostile turbulent wave dark matter ($\Psi$DM) halo of a galaxy                agitates with various kinds of excitation. Soliton breathing at amplitudes on the verge of breakup is also a highlight of this work. The mock solution, constructed from the simulation data, sheds lights on the dynamics of the large-amplitude breathing soliton.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09129v1.title: The parallax and 3D kinematics of water masers in the massive star-forming region G034.43+0.24
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09129v1.summary: The water masers display arc-like distributions, possibly bow shocks, associated with winds from one or more massive young stars. The measured 3-dimensional motion of G034.43+0.24 indicates a near-circular Galactic orbit. This locates the water maser near the inner edge of the Sagittarius spiral arm and at one end of a linear distribution of massiveyoung stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09049v1.title: On the 3D Curvature and Dynamics of the Musca filament
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.09049v1.summary: Filaments are ubiquitous in the interstellar medium (ISM), yet theirformation and evolution remains the topic of intense debate. In order to obtain a more comprehensive view of the 3D morphology and evolution of the Muscafilament, we model the C$^{18}$O(2-1) emission along the filament crest with several large-scale velocity field structures.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07238v2.title: ALMA-IMF. V. Prestellar and protostellar core populations in the W43 cloud complex
http://arxiv.org/abs/2301.07238v2.summary: Recent observations in the W43 molecular complex of top-heavy CMFs raise questions about our understanding of the starformation processes and their evolution in space and time. Protostellar cores are found to be, on average, moremassive and smaller in size than prestellar cores. Our results could be explained by clump-fed models in which cores grow in mass.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08997v1.title: Overall Binary Evolution Theory
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08997v1.summary: Accreting compact objects are crucial to understand several importantastrophysical phenomena. We still do not fully understand how they form and evolve. This chapter will review the current theoretical status of our knowledge of these objects. It will discuss standing problems and potential solutions to these problems.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08952v1.title: First results from the JWST Early Release Science Program Q3D: The Warm Ionized Gas Outflow in z ~ 1.6 Quasar XID 2028 and its Impact on the Host Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08952v1.summary: Quasar feedback may regulate the growth of supermassive black holes, quench                coeval star formation, and impact galaxy morphology. However, direct evidence for quasar feedback in action at the epoch of peak black hole accretion at z ~ 2 remains elusive. A good case in point is the 1.6 quasar WISEA J100211.29+013706.7.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08919v1.title: Short-lived Radionuclides in the Milky Way Galaxy
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08919v1.summary: Short-lived radionuclides (SLRs) have a half-life $leq$ 100 Myr. We have developed GalacticChemical Evolution (GCE) models for SLRs. These models predict the temporal andspatial evolution of SLR abundance trends in the Galaxy.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08918v1.title: A CEERS Discovery of an Accreting Supermassive Black Hole 570 Myr after the Big Bang: Identifying a Progenitor of Massive z > 6 Quasars
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08918v1.summary: We report the discovery of an accreting supermassive black hole at z=8.679, in CEERS_1019. We detect a significant broad (FWHM~1200 km/s) component in the H$\beta$ emission line, which we conclude originates in the broad-line region of an active galacticucleus (AGN) The mass of the black hole is $6.95 (-0.5) x the Eddington limit. We use this presently highest-redshift AGN discovery to place constraints on black hole seeding models.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15689v2.title: VINTERGATAN-GM: The cosmological imprints of early mergers on Milky-Way-mass galaxies
http://arxiv.org/abs/2211.15689v2.summary: We present a new suite of cosmological zoom-in hydrodynamical simulations of Milky-Way mass galaxies. We study how a varying mass ratio for a Gaia-Sausage-Enceladus (GSE) progenitorimpacts the chemodynamics of halo stars. We find markedly different morphologies at $z=0$ following a growing merger.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.16320v3.title: Colliding Ghosts: Constraining Inflation with the Parity-Odd Galaxy Four-Point Function
http://arxiv.org/abs/2210.16320v3.summary: Within canonical models of inflation, no parity-asymmetry can occur. But breaking of the standard assumptions can lead to parity violation within the Effective Field Theory of Inflation. This is also the first time Cosmological Collider signatures have directly been searched for in observational data.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08860v1.title: The Nature of LoBAL QSOs: II. HST/WFC3 Observations Reveal Host Galaxies Dominated by Mergers
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08860v1.summary: Low-ionization Broad Absorption Line QSOs (LoBALs) are suspected to be merging systems in which extreme, AGN-driven outflows have been triggered. We present the first high-resolution morphological analysis of a volume-limited sample.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08849v1.title: Electron-Ion Temperature Ratio in Astrophysical Shocks
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08849v1.summary: Collisionless shock waves in supernova remnants and the solar wind heat electrons less effectively than they heat ions. The values of T$_e$/T$_p$ inferred from the H alphaprofiles of supernova remnant shocks behave differently as a function of Machnumber or Alfv\'{e}n Mach number.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08846v1.title: On the Dynamical Heating of Dwarf Galaxies in a Fuzzy Dark Matter Halo
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08846v1.summary: Fuzzy Dark Matter (FDM), consisting of ultralight bosons, is an intriguing alternative to Cold Dark Matter. FDMhalos consist of a central solitonic core surrounded by a large envelope of excited states. Wave interference gives rise to order unity density fluctuations throughout the envelope. The resulting gravitational potential perturbations are an efficient source of dynamicalheating.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08842v1.title: Multiwavelength monitoring of the nucleus in PBC J2333.9-2343: the giant radio galaxy with a blazar-like core
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08842v1.summary: PBC J2333.9-2343 is a giant radio galaxy at z = 0.047 with a bright central core associated to a blazar nucleus. Large flux increases are observed on timescales shorter than a month, which are interpreted as flaring events.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08838v1.title: Surviving the Waves: evidence for a Dark Matter cusp in the tidally disrupting Small Magellanic Cloud
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08838v1.summary: We use spectroscopic data for Red Giant Branch (RGB) stars in the Small Magellanic Cloud (SMC) to build a mass model of the SMC. We then apply our method to real SMC data, finding that the stars of the cleaned sample are isotropic at all radii. We provide a new, analytic,density profile that reproduces Dark Matter heating behaviour.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08841v1.title: X-HESS: a large sample of highly accreting serendipitous AGN under the XMM-Newton microscope
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08841v1.summary: The bulk of X-ray spectroscopic studies of active galactic nuclei (AGN) arefocused on local ($z < 0.1$) sources with low-to-moderate ($< 0.3$) Eddingtonratio. In this work we present the preliminary results from the analysis of a sample of radio-quiet AGN at $0.06 \leq z \leap 3.3$, based on the 10th release of the XMM-Newton serendipitous source catalogue.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08833v1.title: Feedback in the merging galaxy group NGC6338
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08833v1.summary: The galaxy group NGC6338 is one of the most violent group-group mergers known to date. While the central dominant galaxies rush at each other at 1400km/s along the line of sight, the central gas in the BCGs remains cool. There are also indications ofipientfeedback from active galactic nuclei (AGNs)

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08827v1.title: Simulations of pre-supernova feedback in spherical clouds
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08827v1.summary: We present a one-dimensional radiation-hydrodynamic model of a sphericallysymmetric cloud evolving under the influence of the self-gravity and the feedback from a star cluster forming in its centre. The model is compared to the semi-analytic codeWARPFIELD implementing similar physical processes.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08831v1.title: VISIONS: The VISTA Star Formation Atlas -- I. Survey overview
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08831v1.summary: VISIONS is an ESO public survey of five nearby star-forming cloud complexes. It was designed to build aninfrared legacy archive similar to that of 2MASS. The observations yielded approximately 1.15 million images, which comprise 19 TB of raw data. VISIONS will enable addressing a range of topics, including the 3D distribution and motion of embedded stars.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08813v1.title: A High Fraction of Heavily X-ray Obscured Active Galactic Nuclei
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08813v1.summary: We present new estimates on the fraction of heavily X-ray obscured, Compton-thick (CT) active galactic nuclei (AGNs) out to a redshift of $z \leq$0.8. From a sample of 540 AGNs selected by mid-IR (MIR) properties in observedX-ray survey fields, we forward model the observed-to-intrinsic X-rays ratio. Our results suggests at least 50% of all MIR-selectedAGNs, possibly more.

http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08793v1.title: Modelling of the multi-transition periodic flaring in G9.62+0.20E
http://arxiv.org/abs/2303.08793v1.summary: We present detailed modeling of periodic flaring events in the G9.62+0.20E star-forming region. Our analysis is performed within the framework of the one-dimensional Maxwell-Bloch equations. We find that the variations in flaring time-scales are manifestations of and are best modeled with Dicke's superradiance.
